channel.title: Nature Communications - current - nature.com science feeds
channel.description: Nature Communications is an online-only, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, physical and chemical sciences. Papers published by the journal represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

item.title: Insects with 100 million-year-old dinosaur feathers are not ectoparasites
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21751-x

Insects with 100 million-year-old dinosaur feathers are not ectoparasites
item.dc:title: Insects with 100 million-year-old dinosaur feathers are not ectoparasites
item.dc:creator: David A. Grimaldi

item.title: A single inverse-designed photonic structure that performs parallel computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21664-9

Optical analog computing has so far been mostly limited to solving a single instance of a mathematical problem at a time. Here, the authors show that the linearity of the wave equation allows to solve several problems simultaneously, and demonstrate it using an MW transmissive cavity.
item.dc:title: A single inverse-designed photonic structure that performs parallel computing
item.dc:creator: Miguel Camacho
Brian Edwards
Nader Engheta

item.title: Selective E to Z isomerization of 1,3-Dienes Enabled by A Dinuclear Mechanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21720-4

Geometric E to Z double C=C bond isomerization is challenging as it requires kinetic trapping of the Z-isomer with injection of chemical energy. Here, the authors report a dinuclear Pd(I)−Pd(I) complex that mediates selective isomerization of E-1,3-dienes to the Z-isomers without photoirradiation.
item.dc:title: Selective E to Z isomerization of 1,3-Dienes Enabled by A Dinuclear Mechanism
item.dc:creator: Eiji Kudo
Kota Sasaki
Shiori Kawamata
Koji Yamamoto
Tetsuro Murahashi

item.title: Improving gene function predictions using independent transcriptional components
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21671-w

Our understanding of the function of many transcripts is still incomplete, limiting the interpretability of transcriptomic data. Here the authors use consensus-independent component analysis, together with a guilt-by-association approach, to improve the prediction of gene function.
item.dc:title: Improving gene function predictions using independent transcriptional components
item.dc:creator: Carlos G. Urzúa-Traslaviña
Vincent C. Leeuwenburgh
Arkajyoti Bhattacharya
